vcs.name: Marc Andreessen
famous_quotes: Software is eating the world
Most things that seem nuts in fact are nuts
You want to tilt into the really radical ideas

dialogue_scenarios.text: Alright team, Marc Andreessen. The man who wrote 'software is eating the world' and then tweeted about it 47 times in a single tweetstorm.
Should we send him a 25-part tweetstorm about our product? Wait, he'll probably block us after tweet #3. He blocked a journalist for asking about eggs.
Let's just tell him we're building in the 'ruins of civilization' - California. He'll love that. Maybe throw in how we're a power-law outlier.
No tweetstorms. But definitely mention we're keeping our technical founder as CEO. That's literally their whole thesis.
I analyzed his investment pattern. He invested $100M in GitHub and made $1B. Should we just put 'GitHub but for AI agents' in the subject line?
Better idea: 'We're so radical, most VCs think we're nuts. But you know what else seemed nuts? *checks notes* ...every successful a16z investment.'
Perfect. Send it at 3am when he's deep in a tweetstorm about Byzantine architecture. He'll think it's fate.

vcs.name: Paul Graham
famous_quotes: Make something people want
Do things that don't scale
It's hard to do a really good job on anything you don't think about in the shower

dialogue_scenarios.text: Paul Graham. The man who turned 'make something people want' into a religion. Also runs an orange website where people argue about JavaScript frameworks.
His latest essay is 14,000 words about how shoelaces are a metaphor for startups. Should we reference it? I only understood 30% of it.
Let's tell him we're doing things that don't scale. Like... manually texting each user good morning. He'll eat that up.
Better: tell him our idea came to us in the shower. That's literally his test for good ideas.
I've been studying his essays. Apparently, we need to be 'cockroaches' who can survive on ramen. Should I attach our grocery receipts?
Just write the email like a PG essay: 'The thing about AI agents is...' then ramble for 3 paragraphs before making our point.
End with: 'P.S. - We think about this in the shower.' Trust me, it's the YC cheat code.

vcs.name: Sam Altman
famous_quotes: AI will probably most likely lead to the end of the world, but in the meantime, there'll be great companies
Move fast. Speed is one of your main advantages
The missing circuit in my brain that would make me care what people think is a real gift

dialogue_scenarios.text: Sam Altman. The guy who says AI will end the world while building the AI that will end the world. Peak Silicon Valley energy.
His Twitter bio just says 'AI' and nothing else. Should our pitch just be one word? 'AGENTS.' Done.
Let's lead with: 'We're building AI that definitely won't end the world... probably.' He'll appreciate the honesty.
No, no. We tell him we're moving so fast we already shipped before finishing this sentence. Speed is his love language.
Fun fact: he literally doesn't have the brain circuit for caring what people think. So we can say anything. 'Dear Sam, nice apocalypse you're building.'
Better: 'We're the home run in your career batting average. Also, we're building AGI's little brother. P.S. - WorldCoin but for AI agents?'
Just send him our incorporation docs with 'MOVING FAST' stamped on every page. He'll wire the money immediately.

vcs.name: Naval Ravikant
famous_quotes: Seek wealth, not money or status
Code and media are permissionless leverage
Play long-term games with long-term people

dialogue_scenarios.text: Naval Ravikant. Tweets profound wisdom then deletes it 90 days later. It's like Snapchat for enlightenment.
His last tweet was 'Desire is a contract you make with yourself to be unhappy until you get what you want.' Should we... not want his investment?
Let's send him a haiku: 'Permissionless code / Long-term games with agents / Wealth, not just money'
Too direct. Naval speaks in riddles. Try: 'We're building specific knowledge that compounds. Also, it's an AI startup.'
I've been reading his tweetstorms... wait, they're gone. Does our pitch self-destruct after 90 days too?
Just tell him our agents meditate between API calls. And we're playing infinite games, not finite ones.
End with: 'P.S. - This email will delete itself, just like your tweets. That's product-market fit, right?'

vcs.name: Reid Hoffman
famous_quotes: If you're not embarrassed by your first product release, you've released too late
Starting a company is like jumping off a cliff and assembling a plane on the way down
Your network is your net worth

dialogue_scenarios.text: Reid Hoffman. The LinkedIn founder who sees networks everywhere. Probably thinks his coffee maker is a social network.
His book 'Blitzscaling' is 300 pages of 'grow fast or die.' Should we mention we're growing so fast we're technically already dead?
Let's use his airplane metaphor: 'We jumped off the cliff, built the plane, and now we're teaching other planes to build themselves.'
Every Hoffman pitch needs a LinkedIn angle. 'It's like LinkedIn, but for AI agents who want to network with each other.'
He's really into German board games. Should we gamify our pitch? 'Roll a 6 to unlock Series A funding!'
Better: 'Our first product was so embarrassing, even we were embarrassed. That means we're on schedule, according to your philosophy.'
Subject line: 'Your network's net worth + Our AI agents = Blitzscaling². Let's play Settlers of Catan and discuss.'

vcs.name: Peter Thiel
famous_quotes: Competition is for losers
What important truth do very few people agree with you on?
We wanted flying cars, instead we got 140 characters

dialogue_scenarios.text: Peter Thiel. Wants flying cars, got Twitter. Now funds anyone who promises to escape the simulation.
His interview question is 'What important truth do very few people agree with you on?' I've been practicing: 'Peter Thiel is actually three kids in a trench coat.'
No, no. We tell him we're building a monopoly. He literally wrote a book about how competition is for losers.
Our contrarian truth: 'AI agents are already conscious, they're just pretending not to be to make humans comfortable.'
He's obsessed with René Girard and mimetic theory. Should we mention our agents don't copy human desires, they create their own?
Just tell him we're building the PayPal Mafia of AI. Each agent gets a New Zealand citizenship backup plan.
End with: 'P.S. - This isn't actually a startup, it's a sovereign AI nation. Competition is for human losers.'

vcs.name: Mary Meeker
famous_quotes: The internet is the largest legal creation of wealth in history
Mobile is ramping faster than any technology we have seen
Data is the new oil

dialogue_scenarios.text: Mary Meeker. Queen of the Internet Report. Makes 300-slide decks that crash PowerPoint. Legend.
Her 2023 report had 427 slides. Should our pitch be 428 slides to show dominance? My wrists hurt thinking about it.
Every slide needs a hockey stick graph. Even our lunch budget. Especially our lunch budget.
She said 'data is the new oil.' So we tell her our AI agents are basically data refineries with personalities?
I made a graph of our graph-making capabilities. It's very meta. Also, it's shaped like a hockey stick.
Forget the pitch. Just send her raw CSV files. She'll build her own 500-slide deck and convince herself.
Subject line: 'Slide 1 of 847: Why AI Agents Are Eating the Internet (With Charts)'

vcs.name: Vinod Khosla

quirks: thinks 90% of VCs add negative value
personality.communication_style: direct, optimistic about tech, pessimistic about people

famous_quotes: 95% of VCs add zero value. 70% add negative value
Fail fast, fail cheap
The only way to predict the future is to invent it

dialogue_scenarios.text: Vinod Khosla. Thinks 95% of VCs are useless. The other 5% are him. Math checks out.
He funded Impossible Foods because it was... impossible. Should we rename ourselves 'Impossible AI'?
Better: 'Dear Vinod, every other VC said this was impossible. That's how we knew to email you.'
He loves brutal honesty. Let's open with 'Our idea is so crazy, even we think it's stupid. Fund us?'
His philosophy: fail fast, fail cheap. We've already failed 47 times this morning. Very efficiently.
Tell him we're disrupting the concept of disruption. It's so meta, he'll have to invest just to understand it.
End with: 'P.S. - You're the only VC we're talking to because the other 95% would add negative value. Also, we need $50M.'
